Distant Reading

An analysis of "Rinconete y Cortadillo" using computational techniques

Close Reading vs. Distant Reading

Distant reading is an approach towards literary analysis generally attributed to Franco Moretti (see, for example, this article). It stands in opposition to close reading: whilst close reading focuses on paying close attention to the content of individual texts, distant reading purposefully abstracts from the particularity of textual content. Instead, it seeks to find, observe, and visualise global features and patterns within a large corpus of texts.

This latter point must be stressed: distant reading concerns huge amounts of textual data, collected either synchronically or diachronically, and analysed in order to reveal large-scale literary or cultural tendencies.

Therefore, any distant reading techniques that we apply to a discrete and short text, such as “Rinconete y Cortadillo”, cannot achieve this aim. Nevertheless, distant reading techniques can be applied to a shorter text in order to prove and bolster quantifiably claims that a competent literary critic may make via intuition alone. Moretti calls this process ‘operationalizing’.

Hypothesis

The following distant reading analysis will carry out several computations in order to investigate, quantify, and visualise the following intuition:

Within “Rinconete y Cortadillo” there is a noteworthy imbalance between narration and character dialogue, which renders the short story more reminiscent of a dramatic text than a text written in prose

This hypothesis is seemingly manifest at many moments during the narrative:

  • During the story’s opening, syncopated dialogue between the two young boys, Rinconete and Cortadillo, with very little narrator intervention or comment
  • During the second half of the story, after entering into Monipodio’s brotherhood, when the dialogue between Rinconete and Cortadillo diminishes dramatically, and the two characters morph into observers of the dramas that unfold there
  • During the musical interlude in Monipodio’s patio when Escalanta uses her clog as a tambourine, Gananciosa uses a broom as another impromptu instrument, and Monipodio smashes a plate to do the same, before all breaking out into song (this scene is pictured in the image at the top of this webpage)

Whilst this hypothesis is inevitably marked by subjectivity - “noteworthy”, “imbalance”, and “reminiscent of” are qualitative terms - distant reading tools and techniques may nevertheless help us to prove or disprove its essence.

Initial Investigations


The first step we can take to carry out distant reading on the text is to upload the text onto Voyant Tools (link) in order to retrieve a visualisation of the text’s most common words, visualised to the right.

From this, we learn that the most frequent word in the story is “dijo” (103 instances), followed by “Monipodio” (96 instances), followed by “respondió” (62 instances).

Despite being the title characters, Rinconete (55 instances) and Cortadillo (50 instances) are only mentioned by name half as much as Monipodio (event taking into account the name change that happens for both characters from Rincón and Cortado respectively which is reflected in these figures).

The graph to the left visualises the intensity with which Monipodio, Rinconete, and Cortadillo are referenced throughout the duration of the text. We can clearly see: references to Rincón and Cortado at the text’s opening are high, drop around midway through the text when they meet Monipodio, to whom references soar, with references to Rinconete and Cortadillo never even reaching the heights of the text’s opening. This supports the hypothesis that the two title characters become bystanders to the ‘Monipodio Show’ as the text progresses.
